status_message: Rupert Murdoch's Australian newspapers are stepping up their campaign to oust Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd and his ALP government. On Saturday the group's most influential newspaper The Daily Telegraph ran a triple-page spread headlined "HERO or PSYCHO?" "An ego-driven, secretive, control freak narcissist or just a man on a mission," was the sub-headline. Readers could have been left wondering whether in fact the article was about Rudd, or about the newspaper's proprietor Rupert Murdoch. Of course it was about the Aussie PM. There was his large photo with him adjusting his spectacles. And of course the byline: Andrew Carswell psychoanalyses Kevin Rudd. So readers are then put through three pages of Carswell's analysis of Rudd's personality and behaviour, trying to draw comparisons with traits of a psychopath. As the basis for his "story" he uses a remark made on Twitter one-and-a-half-years ago by Steve Gibbons in which he referred to the Australian prime minister as such notwithstanding, as Carswell says, "Gibbons is a man who is routinely and rightly pilloried for making crude, stupid and nasty remarks in the name of cheap publicity." Well it seems Carswell himself and his employer, are happy to be a tool of that 'cheap publicity,' long after the remark was tweeted. "So is it true? Is the man running this country really a psychopath?" asks Carswell. Using as his experts on the subject psychotherapist John Clarke, who says between 1% and 3% of all Australians "could be certifiably deemed psychopathic," anthropologist Stephen Juan who suggests one in ten companies are headed by a corporate psychopath, criminal mind expert Steve van Aperen who claims one of the misconceptions about psychopathy is that people think a psychopath goes out and kills people. The Telegraph reporter also refers to a 'psychopathy checklist' put together by Canadian criminal psychologist and FBI adviser Robert D Hare twenty years ago. Drawing an even wider bow he quotes research by Western Sydney University professor Peter Jonason who claims while Machiavellianism is apolitical in its nature, there is a "left-leaning bias for those individuals high on psychopathy." Readers are left with a series of assertions and questions all aimed to portray Rudd as a psychopath: 'It seems psychopaths are everywhere, and they are more likely to wear a suit and tie, than carry a bloodied weapon or be pointing a sawn-off shotgun.' Those deemed psychopathic are very much aware of it, and are attempting to control it. "The corporate psychopath is the type of psychopath that gets into politics because they are usually exceedingly ego-oriented - it is all about them. So even when they get criticism, it is still all about them" (Anthropologist Stephen Juan). "There are certainly many undiagnosed psychopaths in business and politics" (criminal mind expert Steve van Aperen). "...often people get confused between the terms psychopath and psychotic, which makes people less inclined to label someone as the former and thus grouping them with such fiends as Ivan Milat, Charles Manson or Martin Bryant" (Juan). "The corporate psychopath is the type of psychopath that gets into politics because they are usually exceedingly ego-oriented - it is all about them. So even when they get criticism, it is still all about them" (Juan). "They love the centre of attention. Good or bad they see themselves being the centre of the universe" (Juan). "They are the great users, the great manipulators, they often have aides and underlings do work for them, and expect blind loyalty but they don't give loyalty in return. They use everyone for gain" (Juan). "Everything is about them. If you talk to them in a conversation about your issues, they will immediately turn it around to their issues. It's as if no one exists other than them" (Juan). "They climb the corporate ladder very effectively, they are often very charming and articulate, often very good looking which they use to their advantage" (Juan). It is the only thing they exist for. Themselves. They can't be trusted, they will lie to your face and deny they have when they are caught. They never own up to their own actions, they are always blaming others. They are polar opposites in public and private, with the former a place for their charm offensive to be exercised, and the latter a dark place of indifference and loathing (No attribution). It's the psychopath's modus operandi; a persona that they can't escape from, a disguise that soon becomes arduous to hide (No attribution). 'Its (psychopathy checklist by Canadian criminal psychologist and FBI adviser Robert D Hare)  defined set of traits include impulsiveness, superficial charm, grandiosity, callousness, manipulative, lack of remorse or guilt, propensity to blame others, poor behavioural control, egocentric.' Whether unfairly or resoundingly just, Kevin Rudd's name has oft been etched beside those traits, by members of his own camp or from across enemy lines. His impulsiveness is well documented, from rushed decision making done without proper consultation with colleagues or stakeholders, to his "policies on the run" such as the changes to the Fringe Benefit Tax system that crack down on salary-sacrificed cars, to the detriment of the struggling car industry (Carswell). On these rash methods, he is internationally renowned (Carswell). "He makes snap announcements without consulting other countries or within the Australian government" (Unnamed U.S. Embassy official). "I mean this guy is a once-in-a-century egomaniac" (Former ALP leader Mark Latham). Carswell points to a News Corp poll of 30,000 voters last month where voters were given a list of words to describe Rudd. The results were stark sasy The Daily Telegraph reporter: smug, manipulative and egotistical. Claude Minisini spent 15 years within the FBI's behavioural science division. In his opinion, Kevin Rudd is your classic organisational psychopath. Ticks every box, allegedly, wrote Carswell in his article on Saturday. "One of the traits of a psychopath is a lack of remorse. Has Kevin Rudd shown that? In relation to the pink batts saga, has he ever come out and said sorry to individuals for him making that bad decision? The answer is no," Ms Minisini said. "Is he indifferent, or does he rationalise having hurt or mistreated someone else? I suppose he ticks that box too. I would certainly say that he is impulsive. Has he failed to adequately plan ahead? I suppose he ticks that box too. Is he irritable and aggressive? Yes, he probably ticks that one" "There would be some people that would say that he is (a psychopath), given in his early administration, many of his aides left because he was difficult to work with" (Yuan). "You can see these traits in many politicians, not just Kevin Rudd. He has tendencies that are very egotistical, ego centred, but is it only about him? That is the real issue" (Yuan). Oxford University research psychologist Kevin Dutton, Carswell says, is another believer that psychopaths can actually lead incredibly successful lives. "When psychologists talk about psychopaths, what we're referring to are people who have a distinct set of personality characteristics, which include things like ruthlessness, fearlessness, mental toughness, charm, persuasiveness and a lack of conscience and empathy," he said. The article goes on. Inevitably readers are left with the conclusion Rudd is a psychopath. The experts however fell short of that claim. "While Rudd may exhibit some psychopathic tendencies, it is near impossible for an outsider to officially determine," Juan was quoted a saying. "They would have to get to the bottom of their motivations," he said. "There would be some people that would say that he is (a psychopath), given in his early administration, many of his aides left because he was difficult to work with." "You can see these traits in many politicians, not just Kevin Rudd. He has tendencies that are very egotistical, ego centred, but is it only about him? That is the real issue." said Juan. Indeed Carswell has portrayed many who would partly or wholly align with the traits of a psycho. The way Carswell has set out his article he could for example be talking about his bosses, particularly News Corp chairman Rupert Murdoch. He could be talking about Col Allan, the New York Post editor who is Mr Murdoch's envoy to the Australian newspapers on  a mission apparently to destroy Kevin Rudd, which it must be said he is doing a good job of with articles like these. Carswell quotes Emory University's Scott Lilienfeld's who says, "Some psychopathic traits, such as interpersonal dominance, persuasiveness and venturesomeness, may be conducive to acquiring positions of political power and to successful leadership." A research paper by Lilienfield  put Winston Churchill and Lyndon Johnson as perfect case studies, claiming both possessed very real characteristics of a psychopath, but who "managed to parlay these traits into political success." What Carswell didn't relay was perhaps a good summing up of his 'essay,' which is what Oxford University research psychologist Kevin Dutton said in the same Q&A article from Time that Carswell lifted his quote from when asked: "Would you agree that without psychopathic traits, we might lose a lot of leaders and heroes?" Dutton replied, "There's always been a need for risk-takers in society and a need for ruthlessness, charm, charisma and a need for mental toughness and emotional detachment." "All of these traits are on a spectrum, just as there exists no official division  between someone who plays the piano well and a concert pianist. One individual might be ruthless and fearless, but not have a lack of conscience," he said. "If you've got loads of these traits all turned up to max, you're going to overload the circuits [and be a dangerous psychopath]." "But you wouldn't be anywhere near dangerous if some were high and some low," said Dutton. "Depending on context, you're talking different proportions that might be quite functionally adapted to whatever professional field of endeavour you might be working in. [At extremely high levels], you might have problems but if turn those down, you might find people who are better than normal in certain aspects."

status_message: The vicious attack by media mogul Rupert Murdoch on Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd accelerated on Thursday. Murdoch's most influential newspaper The Daily Telegraph portrayed Rudd and the deputy prime minister in Nazi uniforms comparing them to characters of the 1960s/70s sit-com Hogan's Heroes. Kevin Rudd is depicted as the hapless Colonel Klink, who as commandant of a fictitious prisoner of war camp, was a main character in the series. Deputy Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is portrayed as Klink's deputy, Sergeant Schultz. Craig Thomson, a New Zealander and former health union official who is an Independent member of the Australian parliament (formerly a member of Rudd's ALP) and who is facing fraud charges relating to his time with the Health Services Union is also in the photo montage - as Colonel Hogan, the hero of the TV series. The Telegraph story hinges on Albanese having drinks with Thomson, with the basic theme that the meeting had "undermined Kevin Rudd's claims he is forging 'a new way' for the ALP. It is not the first time News Corp newspapers have portrayed public figures in Nazi dress. In 2005, the media group's UK newspaper The Sun was provided with a photo of Prince Harry wearing a swastika armband to a friend's costume party. It was a private function which was also attended by Prince William. That should have been the end of it. The Sun however splashed the photo on its front page with the headline "Harry the Nazi" in text so big it occupied about two thirds of the page. The story was then picked up by almost every news media outlet around the world with the photo appearing in all major newspapers and on TV channels across the globe. While many around the world chastised the 20-year old Harry, not a word was said about Murdoch who had jumped on a chance to profit from the young prince's mistake and was more responsible than anyone for the photo's global exposure. In response to the Murdoch campaign against the Labor government, Kevin Rudd has questioned the media mogul's motivation suggesting it may have something to do with his government's rolling-out of the NBN (National Broadband Network) which some say will be a threat to Foxtel, 50% owned by News Corp. Murdoch has denied this saying the NBN will be advantageous for Foxtel. On Friday News Corp's national newspaper The Australian ran a front page story headlined, "NBN is good for business: Foxtel unpicks PM's conspiracy theory." Warlier in the week (Wednesday) News Corp issued a statement saying, "Any suggestion that the editorial position of our newspapers is based upon the commercial interests of Foxtel demonstrates a complete ignorance of both our business and of Foxtel." Opposition Leader Tony Abbott says he has never talked to Murdoch about the NBN. "Have I ever spoken to Rupert Murdoch about the NBN? No I haven't, no I haven't," he told a press conference in Tasmania where he was campaigning on Thursday. "Senior politicians have to accept that sometimes media outlets will back them and sometimes they won't," he added. Opposition communications spokesman Malcolm Turnbull, who has long championed the Packer and Murdoch families 'entitlement' to share the Australian media landscape, has been a little more circumspect. Asked whether he had discussed the coalition's policy on the NBN Turnbull replied, "I haven't discussed it with him in those terms, in terms of our specific policy," he said. "But I can tell you that Murdoch's views are nothing special," he added. "He's an original thinker and a great entrepreneur and businessman but when it comes to the NBN he's not saying anything that just about every other businessperson in Australia is not saying." Australian Greens leader Christine Milne without commenting on the News Corp chief's motivation says there is no doubt, "Mr Murdoch's interests are running a massive campaign against the Labor Party and the Greens to get the coalition in."

status_message:
(Big News Network) SYDNEY - "Should I not be prime minister by the end of this campaign let there be no doubt that my challenger will be a puppet of Rupert Murdoch. That is the reality, that is the choice at stake," Rudd said. This is not a statement made by Australian Prime Minister Kevin Rudd but could have been. This in fact is a statement made by former NSW Premier Nathan Rees on December 3 2009 and he wasn't talking about Rupert Murdoch, he was talking about Eddie O'Beid. O'Beid has long since fallen from grace after nearly two decades of manipulating leader leadership elections and candidate pre-selections across New South Wales, and then using those who benefited from those political favours to win concessions for his own commercial interests, which blossomed during his time at the helm as the state's power broker and king maker. Rupert Murdoch has a similar history of backing those who bend his way. He has been on the end of some spectacular concessions by premiers and prime ministers, who in turn have benefited from his patronage. The September 7 2013 Federal election however marks a new turn for the Murdoch press. Never has a media proprietor of such magnitude so brazenly come out and attacked a sitting government or an opposition to the extent Murdoch has struck out this time at Kevin Rudd's Labor Government. News Corporation's campaign kicked into high-gear on Saturday with negative headlines and stories emblazoned across the two thirds of Australian newspapers the media giant owns. Following the announcement of the election result on Sunday, Murdoch newspapers upped the ante. Australia's most influential daily newspaper, read by the largest number of readers in the country awoke on Monday to a demand from Murdoch to 'KICK THIS MOB OUT.' (This) "is a classic example of Murdoch's penchant for political character assassination. There is not the slightest attempt to conceal his agenda. It is blatant, bold and belligerent. And it confirms yet again the way in which he links political interventions to his commercial desires," The Guardian said in a front page article published Tuesday. "He (Murdoch) is a past master at this business and appears to have chosen one of his most loyal editorial lieutenants to oversee what is certain to be an uninhibited five-week assault on Rudd and his Labor colleagues." The Guardian, as other non-Murdoch newspapers are talking about, was referring to Col Allan, a former Daily Telegraph editor who for some years has been Murdoch's head man at his New York Post newspaper. He is the person who set-up Rudd on a visit to New York taking him to a strip club, only to have the story of it published at a later time in the Murdoch newspaper network. 
Allan is known among colleagues as Col Pot, comparing him to the ruthless dictator who eradicated 25% of his countrymen when he ruled Cambodia (formerly Kampuchea) as leader of the Khmer Rouge in the late 1970s. Murdoch has long waged a war against the Rudd (and Gillard) government after it set up the National Broadband Network (NBN) which the media mogul sees as a threat to the profitability of Foxtel, half-owned by News Corp. 
Murdoch is said to be fearful too of Labor's likelihood of setting up a press regulatory body similar to ACMA which oversees the broadcasting and television industries. The Daily Telegraph headline of Monday has caused surprise in some circles, and has resulted in widespread media comment including being the starting topic on QandA on Monday night. "I think Australians are a bit smarter than looking at that headline and going oh well, that must be right. They will look for what the agenda is behind the headline," Deputy Prime Minister Anthony Albanese said Monday. 
"It's not terribly subtle and in terms of the media, I reckon Telegraph readers will be picking that up and thinking, 'Well I deserve better than that as a Telegraph reader'. That is an extraordinary intervention on day one of an election campaign."
The Daily Telegraph in an editorial on Monday titled "Consign Rudd to the bin of history" defended its position, after noting the newspaper endorsed Kevin Rudd in the 2007 election. "It is traditional for newspapers to deliver their verdict on the eve of the election, but we would like to offer our judgement in a calm and measured way now, unaffected by the relentless spin and sloganeering which is about to cloud the coming campaign," the editorial said. "At the same time we will place Coalition policies under exactly the same level of scrutiny," The Daily Telegraph editorial added. Rupert Murdoch may well be demanding the votes of readers of The Daily Telegraph and his other newspapers around Australia. He doesn't have a vote himself. Facing a ban on foreigners owning television assets in the United States, Rupert Murdoch to advance his commercial interests in 1985 surrendered his Australian citizenship and became a naturalised U.S. citizen. (The following year Murdoch's company established Fox which now reaches 96% of households in the United States).

status_message: The honeymoon for Kevin Rudd and Australia's Labor Government is over.  Rupert Murdoch's network of Australian newspapers has thrown down the gauntlet, just as they have in past years. August 3 2013 is the day. The day the Murdoch-controlled newspapers kicks off their campaign to boot Rudd out of the lodge. On Saturday August 3 almost half the front page of The Daily Telegraph is taken up with three words "Price of Labor." In large text underneath in red are the words "Another huge budget shamblesnow we're $30b in the red." A photo of a hapless looking Rudd accompanies the so-called story. Only it's not a story, it's a teaser with a paragraph about "Australia haemorrhaging under a $22 billion budget blowout in 80 days, and warnings of decade-high unemployment." The teaser takes readers to pages 4 and 5 where the News Corp strategy is laid out with a string of negative articles. The largest blazoned by a huge headline in capital letters across the two pages is titled, "LABOR'S DEBT AND JOBS CRISIS." Other headlines include, "Soaring costs are big issue for voters," "Debt pushes us to edge of the fiscal cliff by Christmas," "Stop being childish and start running the country properly," and "No safety in these numbers for  Rudd." That was just pages 4 and 5. Elsewhere in the newspaper we see, "Sending refugees to PNG costs $1b," and the lead story in the Business section, "Elect Rudd if you want higher taxes and deficits." The second most prominent story on the page is, "Muddled strategy threatens prosperity." On the opinion page is a photo of Treasurer Chris Bowen gritting his teeth and a large opinion piece headlined, "Mr Tough Guy, eh?" Adjacent to that is the newspaper's editorial for the day, attacking the Labor Government. The headline is, "Labor leading us into a black hole." It blasts the government over its economic forecasts, how they've changed estimates since the May budget and it sends up Bowen's characterisation that Australia is not in crisis but is in transition mode, and that it needs careful economic management. The Telegraph is the most influential  daily newspaper in Australia's biggest state. It normally focuses on human interest stories, sport and entertainment. Its readers must be left wondering why they're being inundated with negative stories about the economy and the government. Well they should get used to it. This is the first of a barrage of articles, headlines and editorials to come in Murdoch's quest to rid itself of the Australian government. Rupert Murdoch wants and needs every Daily Telegraph reader's vote. News Corp wants a government that suits its commercial interests and it clearly intends to influence its readers in every way it can. What has appeared in The Daily Telegraph on August 3 is appearing in one form or another in every Murdoch newspaper across the country and that counts. Why? Because News Corp controls two thirds of all daily newspapers in Australia. In the group's national newspaper The Australian the lead story is headlined, "Bad news on jobs, deficit and growth." Below that is an 'exclusive,' titled "Revealed: How Rudd blew $250bn." Next to that is a red background teaser "Budget Turmoil," pointing to several articles elsewhere in the newspaper. Stories such as, "Let's face it: Treasury, Bowen have no clue," "Another set of 'rushed proposals," "Treasurer's assumptions are flaky," "ALP to lift ceiling for its deficits," "Cost of Rudd's PNG Solution will be a topic of hot debate," "Tough disability rules to save Canberra $457m," "Union snubs Labor campaign," "Rivers of cash in pre-poll spend," "Bowen using development funding as a 'honey pot'," and "Unemployment to hit GFC high." The front page of the newspaper's 'Inquirer' supplement is headlined "The $250bn cost of Kev," and goes on to outline the views of two economists who have determined "The prime minister's time in office has been marked by waste and spending on an extraordinary scale." The main story meantime doing the rounds on News Corp websites News.com.au, The Sun-Herald and The Courier-mail is titled, "Tony Abbot says the Coalition is ready for the 2013 election." So too is seems is Rupert Murdoch. (Footnote. In November 1975 all 109 journalists at The Australian went on strike in the middle of the federal election campaign arguing their newspaper was biased. Seventy five of the journalists signed a letter to Rupert Murdoch complaining of, "the deliberate and careless slanting of headlines, seemingly blatant imbalance in news presentation, political censorship and, more occasionally, distortion of copy from senior specialist journalists, the political management of news and features, the stifling of dissident and even palatably impartial opinion in the papers' columns.").

status_message: Last month James Packer the Chairman of Crown Limited wrote to Chris Eccles the Director General of the NSW Premier's Department outlining the attributes he believed his company's proposal for a "six star hotel casino" at Barangaroo (in Sydney, Australia) would bring to New South Wales. In the letter Mr. Packer said Crown "will make an upfront payment of up to $250 million to the NSW Government upon the issue of the VIP gaming license." Within two weeks of receiving the Packer proposal, and a separate proposal from Echo Entertainment, the government had decided to accept Mr Packer's bid. But not quite. The license fee offered by Crown had been whittled down to $100 million. In the premier's press release on the day the decision was announced, Barry O'Farrell advised taxpayers the state would receive an upfront fee of $100 million. There was no mention of the fact that Crown had offered $250 million. So did Mr O'Farrell manage to beat Mr Packer down to a lower price? Not quite. The Packer bid included two proposals. One, an offer to pay $250 million with certain tax rates, and the other for $100 million with lesser tax rates. The tax proposed is worth noting. As we have reported previously the bulk of tax that will be paid by Crown Sydney will be tax on international and interstate VIP revenue which Crown proposed be 10% under the $100 million upfront license fee regime, and 9% under the $250 million scenario. For the lesser revenue-generating VIP local gaming the tax was proposed at 23% if the license fee was $250 million, or 27.5% if it was $100 million. The Assessment Panel recommended this be lifted to 29%, not the 27.5% Crown proposed. What the O'Farrell government has done is forfeit $150 million of the offered upfront fee to receive an extra 1% of the majority of tax to be raised, and an extra 6% tax of the lesser revenue. As we've pointed out before all tax rates for casinos in Australia include GST, so the effective tax rate for 10% would be less than 1% at 0.09%, in other words less than one tenth of 1%. The 29% after GST of 9.09% and a responsible gaming levy of 2%, will yield the government an effective tax rate of 17.91%. Regardless the Assessment Panel recommended to the government the $100 million option saying it did so, "because it provides the opportunity for taxpayers to receive a greater share of the upside if Crown's proposal is successful, and because it maximises competitive neutrality if The Star's tax rates are maintained at current levels when renegotiated in FY2020." Deloitte Access Economics was asked by the Premier Department's Assessment Panel to assess the two offers. No-one knows the brief they were given, but anyone with a calculator assessing present day values would have great difficulty in concluding the merit of knocking back $250 million in favour of $100 million, even if there was a case for what would have to be very skinny gains especially when they're based on forecasts that start six years into the future and are then extrapolated out many years again. Deloitte, the only independent expert it seems consulted by the Assessment Panel, did in fact have difficulty in doing that. Using four different scenarios, including Crown's forecasts and their own, Deloitte concluded whichever way it was looked at the $250 million offer for the Sydney license would provide a superior return to the NSW government. Their report said as much, putting the figure at $48 million. Despite this, Deloitte did say if the government wanted to take a risk it could "capture a greater share of any upside," if it went for the $100 million option because of its higher tax rates. Their report actually makes reference to the potential for higher-than-anticipated growth in local VIP gaming, which both the casino's promoters and the government are trying to play down. The Deloitte report also makes a curious reference to international tax regimes saying there is potential for them to change beyond 2019 implying that this could be some sort of justification for accepting the lower upfront license fee. How the Assessment Panel relying on Deloitte's conclusions could determine the $100 million offer was better than the $250 million offer and in the best interests of NSW taxpayers is anyone's guess. One thing is certain, the people of New South Wales were not even told of the $250 million offer. The premier made no mention of it in his announcement at Parliament House earlier this month, in fact he said the $100 million was a condition of the government's approval. An upfront lump sum was always on the table and subject to legislation being enacted this year, which is extremely likely, it will be paid this year. Crown has promised that. So the O'Farrell government will knock back $250 million to be paid this year and instead accept $100 million so that in seven years time it can start to receive an extra one tenth of 1% of the majority of tax it collects, plus 6% of the lower local VIP revenue. The premier at the time of his announcement imposed four other conditions one of which was that Crown had to guarantee the state will receive a minimum $1 billion in license fee and gaming taxes in the first 15 years. What he didn't say is Crown had offered a guarantee of $1 billion in gaming taxes alone, nothing to do with the upfront fee. Again the government appears to have foregone another significant amount, $100 million in the form of a guarantee. This was not explained but should have been. To trumpet that Crown would be asked to pay 29% tax, instead of the 27.5% it proposed, but then not to say what had been conceded was not good. It was also not good to be only talking (in his announcement) of the local VIP tax when the essence of the Crown proposal is that its casino will primarily cater for overseas and interstate VIP gamers, paying significantly less, almost negligible, tax. The lack of transparency is disturbing. The premier has not indicated what the term of the license is to be. As he has been silent on that issue one can only assume the length of the license will be 99 years, the term proposed by Crown. Deloitte did a comparison of the two Crown license fee options and failed to provide any insight on whether what was being proposed was an appropriate value, particularly given the 99 year term of the license. It would appear the Assessment Panel, overseen by the Steering Committee, did little to satisfy itself of the value of the license which will allow Crown to particpate in the VIP market, which internationally alone according to Deloitte, using Crown's estimation, turned over $2.5 trillion last year of which Australia had a 2.5% share. No-one in terms of Deloitte, the Assessment Panel or the Steering Committee, or David Murray thought to obtain an independent valuation of the casino license they are all engaged in the process of recommending be awarded. In the United States casino licenses in states where there are multiple casinos are going for hundreds of millions of dollars, with some of those states charging up to 50% in tax. In 2004 Illinois put a licence up for tender and it brought $518 million (US dollars). Illinois has ten casinos, New South Wales has one. The tax rate for gaming in Illinois is 50%, and that is on all forms of gaming. Crown Melbourne's license, which was for 40 years (it expires in 2033) cost $300.8 million, and that was in 1993 (twenty years ago). If indeed the O'Farrell government has agreed to grant a 99 year VIP gaming license for the sum of $100 million that would be an extraordinary occurrence, particularly when it was offered $250 million. It should be pointed out one of the other 4 conditions the government has imposed is that license fee and tax be independently reviewed after 20 years. That may mean a review of the license fee then although the report is far from clear on that. Even if it was, there remains little sense in rejecting $250 million to be paid now, in place of $100 million plus minor and uncertain incremental tax from 2020 with a revision of the fee (if in fact it is to occur) in 2040. Deloitte, has tried valiantly to defend the case, probably at the behest of the Assessment Panel, which reviewed Deloitte's draft findings before they were finalised, but as Deloitte concluded the government would actually receive a net present value of $48 million greater by accepting the $250 million offer (and concluding it using four different scenarios), the people of New South Wales must be left wondering what is going on. The problem is they don't know what is going on. There is virtually no media or parliamentary scrutiny of the process. This has been a VIP members only sale with 60% off. (Source: Big News Network)

status_message:
US Army Private Bradley Manning has been found not guilty of aiding the enemy after leaking government secrets to WikiLeaks.

But the judge, Army Col. Denise Lind, found him guilty of espionage, theft and other charges on Tuesday, more than three years after he spilled secrets to WikiLeaks.

The judge deliberated for about 16 hours over three days before reaching her decision in a case that drew worldwide attention as supporters hailed Manning as a whistleblower.

The US government called him an anarchist computer hacker and attention-seeking traitor.

The intelligence officer who leaked 700,000 classified documents, has been held guilty of five counts of espionage and five theft charges, computer fraud and other military infractions, which could see him sentenced to prison for 136 years.

The 25-year-old Crescent, Okla., native acknowledged giving the anti-secrecy website hundreds of thousands of battlefield reports, diplomatic cables and videos in early 2010.

In his closing statement last week, lead military prosecutor Major Ashden Fein said, "Manning had the general evil intenthe acted voluntarily and deliberately with his disclosures."

When Manning entered his guilty pleas earlier this year he spent an hour reading a statement to the court detailing why he leaked the documents. He explained that he had only released information that "upset" him, and not any that he believed could harm the United States:

"I believed if the public was aware of the data, it would start a public debate of the wars," he said.

Manning's defense team have argued that the intelligence analyst was nave and guilty of negligence but not the "general evil intent" that justifies a conviction for "aiding the enemy". To uphold this most serious charge, the judge must be convinced beyond reasonable doubt that Manning knew the leaked information could end up in the hands of Al-Qaeda.

Manning has, like Edward Snowden, had a large amount of support around the world from people who see him as a hero who stood up to the government.

American blogger Xeni Jardin tweeted that Manning flashed a "faint smile" as he was cleared of the most serious accusation - that he knowingly helped enemies of the US, most notably Osama bin Laden and al Qaeda.

Protestors held balloons placards calling for the release for Pfc. Bradley Manning

Manning's lawyer David Coombs said outside court: "We won the battle, now we need to go win the war. Today is a good day, but Bradley is by no means out of the fire."

WikiLeaks described Manning's espionage convictions as "dangerous national security extremism from the Obama administration" on Twitter.

Manning's family said they were "disappointed in today's verdicts but happy that the judge agreed that Bradley never intended to help America's enemies", tweeted a Guardian journalist.

Manning will be sentenced on Wednesday.

status_message: Despite recent claims to the contrary,  Sydney is flush with new hotels, with many more in the pipeline. It has been extensively reported that only one 5 star hotel has been built in Sydney since 2000. This claim rightly or wrong conveys the impression there has been little in the way of new hotels built in the city in the past 13 years. Nothing could be further from the truth. What should also be understood is that several thousand new rooms were added to the city's hotel inventory in 1999 and 2000 in advance of the Sydney Olympic Games. Since 2000, thousands more rooms, suites and apartments have been added to Sydney's hotel stocks. Five star hotels to open since 2000 include Meriton's World Tower in 2003, Fraser Suites Sydney which opened in 2006, the Diamant Hotel at Kings Cross which opened in 2007, the Pullman at Sydney Olympic Park which opened in 2008, The Star at Darling Harbour and the QT Hotel in George street, both of which opened last year, and the 1888 Hotel at Pyrmont which opened earlier this year. In addition the 5 star Sydney Hilton Hotel was totally gutted and redeveloped in a $200 million revamp. It re-opened in 2005 after being closed for two-and-a-half years. Four and 4.5 star properties have been equally as popular. Last year the 4.5 star Quest Sydney Olympic Park opened its doors. The 4.5 star Courtyard by Marriott Macquarie Park North Ryde opened in September 2005. A budget Formula One hotel accompanied the opening of the Pullman at Sydney Olympic Park while Accor also built a three star Ibis Hotel near King Street Wharf. The 4.5 star Adina Crown opened in 2010. Harry Triguboff's Meriton established its serviced apartments wing in 2003, opening its flagship 5 star World Tower property that year, followed by 4 and 4.5 star serviced apartment hotels in Kent Street (431 apartments), the recently-opened Campbell Street (247 apartments), Bondi Junction (182 apartments), Waterloo (184 apartments), Zetland (334 apartments), and Parramatta (202 apartments). Quest too has been busy in the city and suburbs adding 4.5 star hotels at World Square, Potts Point, Campbelltown, Camperdown, Mascot, Castle Hill, North Ryde, and 4 star venues at Bondi Junction, Quest on Dixon Darling Harbour, and Rosehill Racecourse. And in April this year the 318 room 4.5 star Rydges Airport Hotel opened at the international airport terminal, while the 4.5 star Zara Tower hotel in the city opened earlier this month. In the pipeline, putting aside hotels yet to be announced, there's the new St Giles hotel being built in Hunter Street in the city, the new 5 star Baillies Hotel at The Rocks to be completed next year, InterContinental's first Holiday Inn Express in Australia at Macquarie Park in North Ryde, the 5 star Pacific QT at Bondi Beach, the 5 star InterContinental at Double Bay (the former Ritz-Carlton), the 4.5 star Adina Apartment Hotel Royal Randwick to be completed in 2015, the 4.5 star Adina apartment hotel at Bondi Beach to be completed this year, the 4.5 star Adina Apartment Hotel at Mascot less than a kilometre from Sydney Airport to be completed late next year, and the 4.5 star Adina Apartment Hotel Norwest. Lend Lease, as part of the Darling Harbour Live consortium (previously known as the Destination Sydney consortium) is building a hotel complex of up to 900 rooms (expected to be 4 and 5 star) adjoining the new Sydney Harbour Convention Centre at Darling Harbour, for which it was named the successful tenderer in November last year. That entire complex including the new hotel complex is slated to be open by late 2016. Echo is expected to build an additional 508 room five star hotel at The Star Casino, while the Crown Sydney 5 star hotel at Barangaroo, to be completed in 2018, will add another 350 rooms. In addition Sydney's largest hotel the Four Points by Sheraton at Darling Harbour will extend its 4.5 star room inventory from 672 to 906 rooms, with completion expected in mid-2015.

status_message:
Prosecutors have labeled US soldier Bradley Manning as a traitor who joined the army purposely and with one of the objectives of accessing protected government secrets and passing them on to a group of anarchists. "WikiLeaks was merely the platform that Pfc (Private First Class) Manning used to make sure all the information was available to the world, including the enemies of the United States," Army Major Ashden Fein said in his closing argument of Manning's trial here. "Manning deliberately disclosed compromised information to the world." The prosecutor said he was deployed to Iraq where he doubled up his extensive computer skills and used them for delving into and disclosing a treasure trove of US secrets that he knew would assist terrorist organizations in their efforts to attack the United States. Fein recounted with sharp details the heart of the government's case that Manning personally sought out WikiLeaks as his vehicle for exposing more than 700,000 combat videos, terrorism detainee assessments, State Department cables and other highly secret materials. "He was not a naive soldier," Fein said. Manning, 25, has already pleaded guilty to 10 of the more than 20 counts he faces, and could face life in prison. Fein dismissed the defence's portrayal of Manning as a confused and disillusioned young man, saying that the leak was an abuse of trust while he worked as an intelligence analyst for the Army in Iraq.
"The flag meant nothing to him," Fein said. The prosecutor told the judge, Colonel Denise Lind, that Manning spent untold hours transmitting documents to WikiLeaks and hours more chatting online with WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange and following his orders, and even more time "wiping" his computer clean thinking he could "hide his tracks". "The only human Manning ever cared about was himself," Fein said. "He was interested in making a name for himself." Manning trial, which began in June, is now nearing an end after it began in June. Judge Lind will decide whether Manning was a whistleblower who bravely sought to enlighten the world about government misconduct, especially in Iraq and Afghanistan, or a traitor whose raw betrayal of the United States merits a sentence of life in prison with no parole. The prosecution stressed that the man from a small Oklahoma town committed espionage, endangered this country's national security and aided organizations such as Al Qaeda that continue to plot terrorist strikes against the US. Manning was arrested in May 2010 while serving in Iraq. He spent weeks in a cell at Camp 
Arifjan, a US Army installation in Kuwait.

status_message:
(Big News Network) SYDNEY - New South Wales taxpayers have been told taxation levels from the proposed new Crown Sydney casino complex will deliver tax returns of 29%.

This level of taxation is greater than that proposed by Crown, NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell said in a statement on July 4.

The reality is the majority of tax paid by Crown will be 10% and as that is subject to GST of 9.09%, NSW taxpayers will get less than 1% on tax of the majority of gambling at Crown Sydney.

In announcing earlier this month the progression of Crown's unsolicited proposal to Stage 3, the NSW premier said the government was doing so on the basis of a number of conditions. One was that non-rebate gaming would be taxed at 29% (including GST and the Responsible Gaming Levy) "and not 27.5% as proposed by Crown."

By selectively commentating on one aspect of the proposed tax arrangements, the premier put in play what was inevitably reported in that the tax on gaming at the Sydney casino would be at 29%, which he said was more than what Crown had wanted.

The fact is that the 29% flat rate will only apply to non-rebate gaming revenue.

Given that the bulk of gambling at the proposed VIP gaming facility will be by international gamblers, what he should have said was what the rebate tax would be and that is 10%. Not only does this apply to international gamblers but it also applies to interstate gamblers too.

Further, the 29% rate on non-rebate gaming includes GST and the Responsible Gaming Levy which is 9.09% and 2% respectively, which means the NSW taxpayer will get 17.91%.

The 10% tax too is inclusive of GST but no calculation on that was included in the Assessment Report, prepared by the Premier Department's Assessment Panel or in the Steering Committee's report.

As the Australian Treasury says, "GST is payable at a rate of one eleventh on the player loss of a gambling business, across all forms of gambling (ATO 2009a)," it is clear the 10% on rebate gaming at Crown Sydney will be subject to GST of 9.09%, leaving NSW with a tax take of less than 1% (0.09%).

Crown of course, in both cases, with have all GST reimbursed by the Federal government. One could argue NSW will receive 31% of that 9.09% (2.8179%) back in the GST reallocation, however the Assessment Panel report says, "It is noted that the NSW Government will provide Crown with a rebate of GST paid on international and interstate VIP gaming revenue, in line with practices for The Star." What this exactly means in unclear. The complete lack of clarity on the proposed tax arrangements, given that they are the basis for the government's justification for granting a second casino license, is disturbing.

The reports does say the tax on non-rebate revenue in Sydney currently (at Echo) is 27.5% up to a certain threshold, after which it rises progressively (in $5 million increments) to a maximum of 50%. The NSW government proposes to apply the same 29% flat rate (actually 17.91% net) to Echo when Crown opens. "The Star (Echo) will be transitioned to the same flat rate when its exclusivity period ends," the Steering Committee's report says. Whether they are able to do that or not is not clear. Echo is currently paying an average 28% and with the introduction of Crown, its tax could be lower under its existing formula. It is unknown whether Echo's license agreement provides for changing tax scales. Crown conversely has insisted there be no change in tax charges for the term of its license and that if there are any proposed fees, or additional taxes proposed then they only be so by agreement with Crown, and if they are implemented within the first 30 years of the license, Crown must be compensated. Where the Government stands on that is unclear. A condition recommended by the Steering Committee is that tax levels (for Crown Sydney) be reviewed after the first 20 years of operation.

What is also concerning are the representations, and lackoof representations, made in relation to tax in other jurisdictions which would be of importance in establishing that the proposed rates of taxation are fair and reasonable, and comparative with other markets such as Singapore.

This is particularly relevant as the NSW Government says it is basing its decision on the recommendations of the Assessment Panel which has considered matters such as these and has outlined them out in its report, which was a recommendation to Cabinet.

The only problem is the Assessment Report, which only refers to two other international markets, says by comparison to what is being proposed in Sydney, Singapore has a flat tax rate of 5%, and Macau 35%. These two destinations, Singapore with two casinos, and Macau with 33 casinos, are referred to repeatedly in the Crown application as a mirror of what can be achieved in terms of the benefits that could be achieved for international tourism in Australia. To be advising government the all gaming tax in Singapore is at a flat rate of 5% is just untrue. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore confirms premium players are taxed at 5% but PLUS GST of 7% making a total of 12% (remember the proposed Crown rates are also inclusive of GST), and for other players the rate is 15% PLUS GST of 7% making it 22%. So rather than Singapore charging a flat rate of 5%, Singapore in fact charges 12% for premium players, and 22% for all other players.

This incorrect information demonstrates a serious lack of rigor in the process of assessment of the Crown proposal. One would have thought the Assessment Panel, a wing of the Premier's Department, overseen by a more senior wing of the Premier's Department, would have at least requested information directly from Singapore's IRAS, and for that matter had serious discussions with government and casino regulators in other jurisdictions and reported that information, rather than simply stating things which appear to be untrue.

Such is the nature of the extent of thoroughness by the Steering Committee and the like-structured Assessment Panel that an internal memo from a member of the Stage 1 Assessment Panel to another member of the department dated 26 October 2012, a day after Barry O'Farrell announced the Government was advancing the Crown proposal to the second stage, called for a search on the Internet to obtain information on tax rates in other jurisdictions, and that was for Australian-based casinos where inter-government information requests would have been more readily responded to.

"Would you mind doing a search of Australian casino websites to see what we can discover re tax regimes, license fees and lump sum payments for licenses," the internal memo began. "I understand different jurisdictions have different disclosures. For the moment we'll keep it to a desk top/web site search. If we have to approach jurisdictions we'll do that at some future point."

"Of particular interest," the memo continued, "are Burswood in Perth and Crown in Melbourne (both Crown facilities) but could you also see what we can find for Cairns, Townsville, Brisbane, and Hobart and we should have Star Casino in the mix."

"If it could be tabulated that would be terrific," the memo concluded.

This is all fine for some internal backgrounding but for appraising comparative tax regimes in other jurisdictions to form the basis of an aspect of an assessment for recommending the establishment of a second casino license it falls well short.

The tax rates, the focus on the larger rate whereas the growth potential for the new casino will largely be in lower-taxed rebate gaming is a serious concern. The extent of cannibalisation, which Crown says will be minimal, could in fact erode the government's tax yield if Crown is wrong. To maintain competition the government's plan to tax both casinos at the same rate could lower the tax take from Echo, if cannibalisation does not occur. The most serious question, given the potential growth in VIP gaming is whether the 10% (0.09% net) flat rate is an appropriate tax.

These are issues needing far more consideration than what appears to have occurred, particularly as they involve forecasts starting from 2020 and going several decades into the future.

As it turned out, in the Assessment Panel report Cabinet members were provided virtually no information on comparative tax regimes anywhere in the world (other than wrong information for Singapore, and minimal information about Macau) but for a vague reference to Victorian gaming taxes relevant to Crown Melbourne which said, "Victoria has higher tax rates on rebate based play, and lower rates on non-rebate based play."

In what should have been an important focus of the Assessment Panel report, Cabinet ministers were provided with 5 sentences about tax levels in other jurisdictions, with no actual tax formulas for any casino in Australia (the Echo formula was detailed elsewhere in the report).

There are in fact many issues that appear not to have been addressed in this slap-dash analysis. Existing legislation, and Echo's constitution by law, prohibits any individual or company from holding more than 10% of voting stock in Echo. This was a condition of the granting of the license which followed a far more stringent, and far lengthier process than the current process. As James Packer's family holds 48% of Crown, how will legislators address that? Will Echo now have that condition relaxed to suit Crown, or will James Packer have to divert a large part of his family's holdings? Or will one casino have the ownership restriction, and the other not?

Too many issues and too little time taken to properly and diligently address them. (Big News Network).

status_message: A year ago this week, the usually tranquil coastal town of Burgas, Bulgaria, was shaken when a bomb exploded on a tourist bus, killing five Israeli vacationers and their Bulgarian bus driver. Within hours of the bombing, Israel claimed Hezbollah was responsible for the attack, and began to petition the European Union with renewed vigor to blacklist the group as a terrorist organisation. Bulgaria's government, backed by the UK, soon reiterated Israel's claims, with the interior minister at the time saying the two suspects responsible for the bombing "were members of the military wing of Hezbollah." Yet inconsistencies plagued the investigation, according to critics, and this year has seen a chain of contradictory statements emerging from Bulgaria over whether or not Hezbollah was actually behind the bombing, with the new government at one point distancing itself from the comments made by its predecessor, before returning back to accusing Hezbollah. Bulgaria has yet to complete its investigation into the attack, according to the interior minister. Regardless, it was this, along with a conviction by a Cypriot court against a Lebanese who is said to have confessed to being a courier for Hezbollah, that were listed as the reasons behind the EU decision on Monday to place the group's military wing on its terrorist list. Cyprus, for its part, was reportedly one of the countries opposed to listing Hezbollah's military wing as a terrorist organisation. The decision "shows that no organisation can carry out terrorist acts on European soil, such as the appalling attack in Bulgaria one year ago, without facing the consequences," William Hague, Britain's Foreign Minister, said following the announcement. Some experts, however, say the move by the EU is politically motivated and directly linked to Hezbollah's role in Syria's civil war. The fallout from Syria "This is 100 percent related to Hezbollah's role in Syria, the fall of Qusayr, and the defeat of the Syrian rebels," Amal Saad-Ghorayeb, a political analyst and expert on Hezbollah, told Al Jazeera, referring to the Syrian regime's victory in June in the battle for the strategic town of Qusayr, in which Hezbollah confirmed it played an active role alongside the Syrian army. Jamal Ghosn, editor of Al Akhbar English, talks about the decision by the EU to blacklist Hezbollah. "The West understands the Syrian regime is not going to fall, and so this has pushed the EU to come out with this decision," she said. "This is a PR war where they're trying to brand Hezbollah as terrorists, and equate them to groups like al-Qaeda." Yezid Sayigh, a senior associate at Carnegie Middle East Center in Beirut told Al Jazeera that such a move was more figurative than anything that would have actual impact on the ground, both in Lebanon and in Europe. "This is more of a symbolic move in its impact, as the EU hasn't placed the political wing on the terrorist list," he told Al Jazeera. "Impacts at this stage will be quite limited partly because the contacts between Hezbollah and the EU are limited, and Hezbollah has limited presence and activity in the EU countries." For Sayigh, Hezbollah's role in Syria "hardened" EU positions; some countries which would not have otherwise backed such a decision felt forced to do so. Hezbollah has publicly confirmed playing a military role in Syria alongside the Syrian army, which it claims is limited to border areas where Lebanese are residing, as well as providing security for the Shia religious shrine, Sayda Zaynab, in Damascus. Syria's opposition disputes these claims, accusing the group of playing a more significant role in the ongoing conflict. In Lebanon, the Saudi and US backed March 14 movement, has long held Hezbollah responsible for any security breach in the country, blaming its role in Syria as a direct cause of instability in Lebanon. In May, the Future movement, a faction within the March 14 coalition, accused Hezbollah of having "transformed itself from a resistance to a militia working under Iranian orders". Terrorists or a resistance movement? Hezbollah is no stranger to accusations of terrorism, more so since its involvement in Syria. Formed in the early 1980s in the middle of Lebanon's civil war, the movement was created as a resistance to the Israeli occupation  in Lebanon. Hezbollah (Party of God), a Shia political and military organisation backed by Iran, is deemed to be one of the stronger political factions inside the country, and has a presence within Lebanon's current caretaker government. It has an extensive social welfare programme across the south of Lebanon, the Bekaa Valley, and Beirut's southern suburbs, and it is internationally known for its military operations.

status_message:
SYDNEY - In the face of unprecedented media support and unprecedented access to the office of the NSW state premier, James Packer's Crown Limited has had a whirlwind success in all but attaining a second casino license in Sydney without tender, without scrutiny, and without any real regard for the interests of the people of the state.

The first question NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell failed to ask, failed to address, failed to elicit expert advice on, failed to ask the people of New South Wales by referendum, or even by seeking public submissions, was whether Sydney in fact needed, or for that matter wanted, a second casino.

The premier did not raise the issue in parliament, rather James Packer and lobbyists, former ALP General Secretary, Karl Bitar, and former NSW State Secretary Mark Arbib, neither of whom appear to be on the NSW lobbyists register, went to the premier, members of the Government, the opposition parties and independents and tied up their support direct.

Fast track through the past seventeen months and we have on July 4 Barry O'Farrell announcing that the Crown proposal would proceed to Stage 3 of the unsolicited proposals process. O'Farrell repeatedly referred to the "independent Steering Committee." The Crown announcement to the ASX the same day did the same. Go back some months and it was the "Steering Committee," which would have an 'independent' chairman, David Murray.

Unfortunately there are very few people asking questions. No one in the media has highlighted who is on this Steering Committee that has been instrumental in recommending to the state a casino license be awarded. And no one from the opposition parties has questioned it. If they had the public would have know every aspect of the investigation of the Crown proposal has been an inside job from the start. Take a look at the Steering Committee. It is headed by Barry O'Farrell's right hand man Chris Eccles who is the Director General of the Premier's Department. 

Also on the 3 man committee is the Secretary of the Treasury Phil Gaetjens, and Mark Paterson, the head of the Department of Trade and Investment, Regional infrastructure and Services. No independent persons, no independent experts.

Secondly there is the 'negotiating team,' which doubles sometimes as the 'Assessment Panel.' This is the body of people that actually does the negotiations with Crown and provides the 'rigorous scrutiny.' Who are they? They are virtually one and the same as the Steering Committee, but not quite. They comprise the deputies of the three people on the Steering Committee. Simon Smith is the chairman of the negotiating team. He is one of four deputy director generals in the Premier's Department. Tim Spencer, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, and Mark Duffy, Paterson's nominee are on the team. So when it comes to being independent, there is nothing independent even between the Steering Committee and the Assessment Panel (negotiating team), and certainly far from being independent of the Premier's Department.

Despite the composition of the state's investigating bodies, which were put together by the Premier's Department, the premier on July 4 when announcing Crown Limited's proposal opened his official press release with the statement: "NSW Premier Barry O'Farrell today announced the NSW Government has conditionally accepted the recommendation of the independent Steering Committee to progress to Stage 3 Crown Limited's unsolicited proposal to develop a VIP gaming facility at Barangaroo." 

The Premier's Department press release also said, "An independent Steering Committee, chaired by former Chairman of the Future Fund David Murray AO was appointed to assess both proposals (Echo's and Crown's), with the assistance of Deloitte Access Economics to ensure rigorous and comprehensive appraisal of each."

The statement makes reference to an' independent Steering Committee' five times. It also refers to the report as "Mr Murray's assessment." It makes no mention of the 'negotiating team' which conducted the appraisal and did all of the negotiations. Many commentators in the media have invariably referred to the report as David Murray's report and his assessment, or his decision. It would appear however he had little to do with the process other than serve as a public face for the Steering Committee which left all the 'negotiations' to their offsiders. The process was run entirely by the Premier's Department.

The Assessment Panel (negotiating team) met with Crown representatives 20 times, and Echo representatives twenty times. None of those meetings were attended by David Murray. He attended just two separate meetings with Crown representatives "to receive a briefing on the preliminary final proposal and identify key issues for the assessment."

David Murray was hired on a daily rate. Requirements for his involvement were foreshadowed as being a half-day, once a fortnight, to prepare for and chair meetings. "These meetings will devise and agree on strategy and necessary supporting work, oversight and guide negotiations, provide progress reporting and recommendations for the Government, and sign off on reports for public release as required by the Government," Simon Smith, Eccles deputy wrote in a briefing note on the appointment of the independent chairman. "The person would also need to present a public face for the process, when required to do so by the Government," he said. "The independent person would not be conducting the negotiations. His role is to oversight the process."

We come to the Deloitte report produced for Stage 1 of the Crown process which has attracted some comment, firstly because Deloitte is the auditor for Crown's Macau casino, and secondly because Barry O'Farrell refused to release it to the public, arguing it was a report prepared for Cabinet. He has since relented saying it would be released following Cabinet's decision.

What is unclear is what the Stage 2 process entailed or whether the government received any expert assistance in its negotiations with Crown, other than relying on a second report from Deloitte. This despite the fact that funds had been made available for this purpose. "DPC has reserved resources in its budget to engage top line negotiating, commercial, legal and financial advisory services as required. These would be drawn from Treasury's panel of pre-qualified advisory firms," Smith wrote in a briefing note about the Crown proposal.

Back to Stage 1 and the first Deloitte's report. Deloitte was asked to do a peer review of the Crown submission which included an assessment by The Allen Consulting Group, which was commissioned by Crown Limited. Such is the breathtaking speed of this process is that Deloitte was contacted on the day the Crown proposal was lodged, September 6 2012. By September 17 Deloitte had been engaged and the Premier's Department had a draft copy of their report by September 21. Unless there is some undisclosed process that has occurred, the Deloitte report appears to have provided the only independent scrutiny of the Packer proposal at that point. The Deloitte report, charged on an hourly rate, cost around $20,000. This seems a little light, given the resources available to the State, that so little was done in terms of independently examining the claims of Crown and its consultants. This however was the expectation of the Assessment Panel as the Deloitte report's introduction reads, "Deloitte Access Economics has been asked to prepare a short report reviewing the unsolicited proposal put forward by Crown." As such Deloitte only had half-a-dozen questions relating to the Allen report and none about Crown's lengthy claims. The Assessment Panel, making the crucial first decision to advance the process to Stage 2 met only twice before making their decision. Their report says, "On 14 September 2012 the Premier's Department requested clarification and elaboration of some information provided by the proponent. This clarification was provided on September 18 2012."

So the Premier's Department establishes an Assessment Panel, the first one for Stage 1 comprising the deputy of the Premier's Department Simon Smith, Di Leeson of the Premier's Department and Tim Murphy of Treasury. They requested clarification on some information from Crown. They ask Deloitte to prepare a short report. Deloitte asks 6 questions of Crown's consultants. Deloitte are engaged on 17 September and attend the first meeting of the Assessment Panel on September 19 to discuss their findings, and deliver their report on September 21. Then on October 15 the Assessment Panel report to Cabinet, endorsed by the Steering Committee, recommends Crown's application to Stage 2, provided Cabinet is of the view the government, "would be willing to consider the policy and legislative amendments that would be required to permit a second casino to operate in NSW."

The purpose of the unsolicited proposals process is for the government and the private sector to engage in a transparent and streamlined approach to introduce innovative ideas. It is for projects that are legal. At this time in New South Wales casinos are illegal, but for the one casino license held by Echo. To process an application to legalise a second casino under the unsolicited proposals mechanism is entirely inappropriate. Having unilaterally decided that it was, the Premier's Department recommended to Cabinet it consider granting a casino license a little more than a month after Crown lodged its application after the recommending body having just two meetings and commissioning a $20,000 report on the financial aspects of the proposal and their benefit to the state. 

The people of New South Wales deserve better.

status_message: Bradley Manning faces life imprisonment as a military judge has refused to dismiss the most serious charge of "aiding the enemy" against the army private who leaked classified government documents to the whistleblower website Wikileaks. Manning, 25, has denied the charges saying he did not intend to benefit terrorist groups with the information that he gave Wikileaks but rather his intention was to spark a conversation about America's actions abroad. The judge's refusal to throw out the charge has, according to his lawyers, left a dangerous precedent for individuals who leak information to journalists and that it could affect more traditional news organizations. The government has argued that his actions, that led Wikileaks to publish the leaked information, in turn helped terror groups such as al-Qaeda. Manning's legal team counter-argues that he only shared the information to change US foreign policy. They said that the government had also failed to prove that the private had "actual knowledge" that he was providing intelligence to al-Qaeda. The trial at a military base in Maryland is drawing to a close. "He was knowingly providing intelligence to the enemy," said Judge Colonel Denise Lind after prosecutors argued he "systematically harvested" documents eventually seen by Osama Bin Laden. The judge also asked the government's lawyer if the type of journalistic enterprise mattered when considering the damage to US interests. "Does it make any difference if it's WikiLeaks or any other news organisation  the New York Times, Washington Post, or Wall Street Journal?" Lind asked prosecutor Captain Angel Overgaard. The prosecutor responded that "it would not potentially make a difference".

status_message: There is impunity in India for rape committed by husbands and members of security ...
link_name: Shocking stories of rape streaming out of India

status_message:
India's reputation as a country is becoming increasingly battered by what appears to be an endless stream of shocking attacks on women and children.

The incidence of reported rape cases in India, where there is impunity for rape committed by husbands and members of security forces, is not higher than other countries, but authorities fear the number of unreported cases is distorting the national figures.

On Tuesday alone this week came news of an eight-year-old boy being sodomised by a man in his house in New Delhi, a 3-year-old girl was raped by a twenty-year-old unemployed youth in Bhopal, while in Gurgaon district of Haryana a 50-year old was charged with raping his mother.

Last Sunday eight men abducted 4 girls aged between 12 and 14 from a convent boarding house in the country's east and raped them in a nearby forest.

A 10-year-old girl died in Mumbai last month after being repeatedly raped by four suspects. 

In New Delhi on Wednesday a high official in India's agriculture department was arrested after a complaint from his five daughters alleging that he had repeatedly raped each of them. The women, who have since married, went to police after they found the man had starting raping his granddaughters. The man's wife has also been charged for refusing to report the crimes after being told of her daughters' ordeals. She told her daughters to ignore the raping as it was "a family tradition."

Despite a number of high profile attacks in recent months that have attracted international coverage, the number of reported cases continues to rise. A rape is reported every 20 minutes. Many people across India have joined in protests. One reason for the increasing number of attacks is the judiciary, and their refusal to take a tough stand. The man who sodomised the 8-year-old boy for example was sentenced to just 3 years in prison this week, and was ordered to pay Rs 10,000 Indian Rupees), the equivalent to just $161 in compensation to the victim.

In December, the gang rape and death of a twenty three-year old woman in Delhi triggered demands for criminal law reform in India. The Government set up a three-member committee headed by former Supreme Court Chief Justice JS Verma to review laws against sexual assault. However, in February, the President signed the Criminal Law (Amendment) Ordinance, 2013, which ignored many of the key recommendations of the Verma Committee.

status_message: Big News Network was down for most of Tuesday, as were all sites operated by the group. The network has its server network housed in Toronto, which has been hit by record-rainfall starting on Monday - causing widespread flooding, traffic jams, and extensive power outages. The Toronto Internet Exchange in downtown Toronto, where Big News Network's servers are situated, was hit by severe power disruptions which also affected the air-conditioning at the exchange causing havoc amongst the equipment housed there. Big News Network operates a network of regional, country and city sites through associate companies Mainstream Media Limited and Midwest Radio Network, an Australian media company. Sites in the group aside from Big News Network, include Arab Herald, Europe Sun, Jamaican Times, Sri Lank  Source, Irish Sun, North Korea Times, Pittsburgh Star, Indianapolis Post, San Diego Sun, Maryland Leader, and the News.Net directory of sites which includes United States News.Net, Singapore News.Net, China News.Net, San Francisco News.Net and Beijing News.Net.

status_message:
Interesting to note what people outside the US think of the furore over Ed Snowden. Big News Network is currently running an editorial published today by the Gulf News, the biggest circulating daily newspaper in the UAE. The editorial follows in full:

 On the face of it, Edward Snowden broke US law when he revealed details of its international eavesdropping programme. 

 However, the benefits of his actions to Americans and the international community, by most accounts, outweigh the cost even in terms of national security. The US should give up its efforts to capture and prosecute him; it should grant him a pardon.

 If Snowden and whistleblowers like him have committed a crime, it is one of conscience. His actions were not motivated by personal profit, but by the greater good; he attempted to end wrongdoing by US officials the indiscriminate invasion of privacy. In the past, the prosecution of whistleblowers did not stop others from revealing the abuse of power. Their desire for justice overcame their fear of punishment and this will more often than not continue to be the case.

 A pardon will not open the floodgates to further breaches as laws will continue to be enforced. Rather it will be a recognition that an accountable government accepts and helps its citizens to do the right thing.
